message: I've looked at how nodejs and jQuery and they both look to be using their own custom solutions. Just curious what your favourite JavaScript API docs is and what tools are used to make them?
awesome - I was wondering how backbone.js did their annotated source code: http://documentcloud.github.com/backbone/docs/backbone.html
i'm still a huge fan of labor of love like CodeIgniter's
+1 for docco, we even wrote a Ruby port
Thanks for all the adivce. Docco looks like just what I was looking for. Thx!
dox seems to be like a docco which understands JavaDoc-style annotations: https://github.com/visionmedia/dox

Google have a rather thorough guidelines for writing Closure-flavoured JSDoc style documentation, alas they don't seem to have released a documentation tool which makes use of it (assuming they have one): http://code.google.com/closure/compiler/docs/js-for-compiler.html

Issues with the above: JSDoc gets lost in certain types of JavaScript (building up objects which will act as APIs in Function scopes is one), docco only documents end-line comments out of the box and its style of docs aren't always suited for someone who just wants to use your stuff. Personally, I've ended up hand-cranking with Sphinx and its JavaScript domain.
@cyu do you have an example or link explaining sphinx + js?
I just found out sphinx can be used with languages other than python and am intrigued

@defunkt i personally didn't like much sphinx for documenting javascript. its functionality works perfectly for python, but looks a bit overwhelming for js. i wrote http://mandoojs.com/docs with sphinx, and i'm about to work in a simpler solution based on http://bonsaiden.github.com/JavaScript-Garden/ -- which I REALLY loved.
BTW, anyone wanna go with me on this? :) will be working at nights. (GMT)
